This is an example of [[Unruh radiation]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=White|first1=H.|last2=March|first2=P.|title=Advanced Propulsion Physics: Harnessing the Quantum Vacuum|journal=Nuclear and Emerging Technologies for Space|date=2012|url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/nets2012/pdf/3082.pdf}}</ref> A publication by Feigel (2004)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Feigel|first1=A.|title=Quantum Vacuum Contribution to the Momentum of Dielectric Media|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|date=2004|volume=92|issue=2|page=020404|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.92.020404|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/physics/0304100v1.pdf|arxiv=physics/0304100|bibcode=2004PhRvL..92b0404F}}</ref> raised the possibility of a Casimir-like effect that transfers momentum from zero-point quantum fluctuations to matter, controlled by applied electric and magnetic fields. These results were debated in a number of follow up papers<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Schützhold|first1=Ralf|last2=Plunien|first2=Günter|title=Comment on "Quantum Vacuum Contribution to the Momentum of Dielectric Media"|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|date=2004|volume=93|page=268901|issue=26|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.93.268901|bibcode=2004PhRvL..93z8901S}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Feigel|first1=A.|title=Feigel Replies:|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|date=2004|volume=93|issue=26|page=268902|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.93.268902|bibcode=2004PhRvL..93z8902F}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Tiggelen|first1=B. A.|last2=Rikken|first2=G. L. J. A.|title=Comment on "Quantum Vacuum Contribution to the Momentum of Dielectric Media"|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|date=2004|volume=93|page=268901|issue=26|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.93.268901|bibcode=2004PhRvL..93z8901S}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Feigel|first1=A.|title=Feigel Replies:|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|date=2004|volume=93|issue=26|page=268904|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.93.268904|bibcode=2004PhRvL..93z8904F}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Tiggelen|first1=B. A.|last2=Rikken|first2=G. L. J. A.|last3=Krstić|first3=V.|title=Momentum Transfer from Quantum Vacuum to Magnetoelectric Matter|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|date=2006|volume=96|issue=13|page=130402|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.96.130402|url=http://www.tara.tcd.ie/bitstream/handle/2262/38886/Momentum.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y|bibcode=2006PhRvL..96m0402V}}</ref> in particular van Tiggelen et al. (2006) found no momentum transfer for homogeneous fields, but predict a very small transfer for a Casimir-like field geometry. This cumulated with Birkeland & Brevik (2007)<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Birkeland|first1=Ole Jakob|last2=Brevik|first2=Iver|title=On the Feigel Effect: Extraction of Momentum from Vacuum?|journal=Phys. Rev. E|volume=76|issue=6|page=066605|doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.76.066605|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/0707.2528v2.pdf|arxiv=0707.2528|bibcode=2007PhRvE..76f6605B|year=2007}}</ref> who showed that electromagnetic vacuum fields can cause broken symmetries ([[anisotropy]]) in the transfer of momentum or, put another way, that the extraction of momentum from electromagnetic zero-point fluctuations is possible in an analogous way that the extraction of energy is possible from the Casimir effect.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Obukhova|first1=Yuri N.|last2=Hehla|first2=Friedrich W.|title=Forces and momenta caused by electromagnetic waves in magnetoelectric media|journal=Physics Letters A|date=2008|volume= 372|issue=22|pages=3946–3952|doi=10.1016/j.physleta.2008.03.021|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/0710.2219v1.pdf|arxiv=0707.2528|bibcode=2008PhLA..372.3946O}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=van Tiggelen|first1=B.A.|title=Zero-point momentum in complex media|journal=The European Physical Journal D|date=2008|volume=47|issue=2|pages=261–269|doi=10.1140/epjd/e2008-00027-1|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/0706.3302v1.pdf|arxiv=0706.3302|bibcode=2008EPJD...47..261V}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Cho|first1=Adrian|title=Focus: Momentum From Nothing|journal=Phys. Rev. Focus|date=2004|volume=13|page=3|url=http://physics.aps.org/story/v13/st3|accessdate=28 November 2016|doi=10.1103/physrevfocus.13.3}}</ref> Birkeland & Brevik highlight that momentum asymmetries exist throughout nature and that the artificial stimulation of these by electric and magnetic fields have already been experimentally observed in complex liquids.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=T.|first1=Roth|last2=G. L. J. A.|first2=Rikken|title=Observation of Magnetoelectric Linear Birefringence|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|date=2002|volume=88|issue=6|page=063001|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.88.063001|bibcode=2002PhRvL..88f3001R}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Croze|first1=Ottavio A.|title=Alternative derivation of the Feigel effect and call for its experimental verification|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society A|date=2012|volume=468|issue=2138|pages=429–447|doi=10.1098/rspa.2011.0481|url=http://rspa.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/royprsa/468/2138/429.full.pdf|bibcode=2012RSPSA.468..429C}}</ref> This relates to the [[Abraham–Minkowski controversy]], a long theoretical and experimental debate that continues to the current time. It is widely recognized that this controversy is an argument about definition of the interaction between matter and fields.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Dereli|first1=T.|last2=Gratus|first2=J.|last3=Tucker|first3=R. W.|title=The Covariant Description of Electromagnetically Polarizable Media|journal=Physics Letters A|date=2007|volume= 361|issue=3|pages=190–193|arxiv=ath-ph/0610078|doi=10.1016/j.physleta.2006.10.060|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/math-ph/0610078v1.pdf|quote=Early suggestions by Minkowski and Abraham for the structure of its electromagnetic component in simple media initiated a long debate involving both theoretical and experimental contributions that continues to the current time (see e.g. ...[Feigel (2004)]...)... Although it is widely recognised that this controversy is an argument about definitions [Mikura (1976)]|bibcode=2007PhLA..361..190D}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mikura|first1=Ziro|title=Variational formulation of the electrodynamics of fluids and its application to the radiation pressure problem|journal=Phys. Rev. A|date=1976|volume=13|issue=6|pages=2265–2275|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.13.2265|quote=The energy-momentum conservation law can be derived separately for the material and the field subsystems. The energy-momentum tensor of the total system cannot be split in a unique way into the material and the field parts.|bibcode=1976PhRvA..13.2265M}}</ref> It has been argued that momentum transfer between matter and electromagnetic fields relating to the Abraham-Minikowski issue would allow for propellant-less drives.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brito|first1=Hector Hugo|title=Propellantless propulsion by electromagnetic inertia manipulation: Theory and experiment|journal=AIP Conf. Proc.|date=1999|volume=458|page=994|doi=10.1063/1.57710|url=http://www.intalek.com/Index/Projects/Research/0994.pdf|quote="However, as mentioned previously, the whole system Energy-Momentum tensor is unsymmetrical; this is a rather uncomfortable property for a system assumed to be a closed one...As a conjecture, if ZPF (Zero Point Field) were a physical reality for describing inertia (Haisch, 1994), that “excess” EM momentum could be explained as a form of “directed”, anisotropic vacuum fluctuations of EM energy. The sought extended system would then happen to be space-time itself... The issue is, as shown, highly relevant to “propellantless” propulsion and experiments to definitely settle the question were still missing besides some partialized attempts (James 1968, Walker 1975, Waker 1977, Lahoz 1979), whose results were not conclusive enough. A positive answer for the Minkowski's EM tensor would allow to obtain “jet-less” propulsive effects by EM fields manipulation, on one hand; on the other hand, it could also represents an indirect demonstration of the physical reality of ZPF, as a possible explanation for unsymmetrical energy-momentum tensors of closed systems."}}</ref>
A QVT system seeks to make use of this predicted Casimir-like momentum transfer. It is argued that when the vacuum is exposed to crossed electric and magnetic fields (i.e. E and B-fields), it will induce a drift of the entire vacuum plasma which is orthogonal to that of the applied E x B fields.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=White|first1=H.|last2=March|first2=P.|title=Advanced Propulsion Physics: Harnessing the Quantum Vacuum|journal=Nuclear and Emerging Technologies for Space|date=2012|url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/nets2012/pdf/3082.pdf}}</ref> In a 2015 paper White highlighted that the presence of ordinary matter is predicted to cause an energy perturbation in the surrounding quantum vacuum such that the local vacuum state has a different energy density when compared with the "empty" cosmological vacuum energy state.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=White|first1=Harold G.|title=A discussion on characteristics of the quantum vacuum|journal=Physics Essays|date=2015|volume=28|issue=7|pages=496–502|doi=10.4006/0836-1398-28.4.496|bibcode=2015PhyEs..28..496W}}</ref> This suggests the possibility of modelling the vacuum as a dynamic entity as opposed to it being an immutable and non-degradable state. White models of the perturbed quantum vacuum around a hydrogen atom as a [[Dirac vacuum]] consisting of virtual electron-positron pairs. Given the nontrivial variability in local energy densities resulting from virtual pair production, he suggests the tools of magnetohydrodynamics (MHD) can be used to model the quasiclassical behavior of the quantum vacuum as a plasma.
White compares changes in vacuum energy density induced by matter to the hypothetical [[chameleon field]] or [[Quintessence (physics)|quintessence]] currently being discussed in the scientific literature.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> It is claimed the existence of a “chameleon” field whose mass is dependent on the local matter density may be an explanation for [[dark energy]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Khoury|first1=Justin|last2=Weltman|first2=Amanda|title=Chameleon Cosmology|journal=Phys. Rev. D|date=2004|volume=69|issue=4|page=044026|doi=10.1103/PhysRevD.69.044026|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/astro-ph/0309411v2.pdf|arxiv=astro-ph/0309411|bibcode=2004PhRvD..69d4026K}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Martin|first1=Jerome|title=Quintessence: a mini-review|journal=Mod. Phys. Lett. A|date=2008|volume=23|issue=17n20|pages=1252–1265|doi=10.1142/S0217732308027631|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/0803.4076v1.pdf|arxiv=0803.4076|bibcode=2008MPLA...23.1252M}}</ref> A number of notable physicists, such as [[Sean Carroll (physicist)|Sean Carroll]], see the idea of a dynamical vacuum energy as the simplest and best explanation for dark energy. Evidence for quintessence would come from violations of Einstein's [[equivalence principle]] and [[equivalence principle#Tests of the Einstein equivalence principle|variation of the fundamental constants]]<ref name="Carroll1998">{{cite journal|last1=Carroll|first1=Sean M.|title=Quintessence and the Rest of the World: Suppressing Long-Range Interactions|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=81|issue=15|year=1998|pages=3067–3070|issn=0031-9007|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.81.3067|arxiv = astro-ph/9806099 |bibcode = 1998PhRvL..81.3067C|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/astro-ph/9806099v2.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Carroll|first1=Sean|title=Dark Energy FAQ|url=http://www.preposterousuniverse.com/blog/2011/10/04/dark-energy-faq/|website=preposterousuniverse.com|accessdate=28 November 2016|date=2011}}</ref> ideas which are due to be tested by the [[Euclid (spacecraft)|Euclid telescope]] which is set to launch in 2020.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Clark|first1=Stuart|editor1-last=Amita|editor1-first=Gilead|title=Our Implausible Universe|journal=New Scientist|date=2016|volume=232|issue=3097|page=35|url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23230970-800-cosmic-coincidences-the-universe-is-flat-as-a-pancake/}}</ref>
Systems utilizing Casimir effects have thus far been shown to only create very small forces and are generally considered one-shot devices that would require a subsequent energy to recharge them (i.e. Forward's "vacuum fluctuation battery").<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Forward|first1=Robert L.|title=Extracting electrical energy from the vacuum by cohesion of charged foliated conductors|journal=Phys. Rev. B|date=1985|volume=30|issue=4|pages=1700–1702|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.30.1700|url=http://www.zpower.com/wap/documents/ZPEPaper_ExtractingElectricalEnergyFromTheVacuumByCohesionOfChargedFoliatedConductors.pdf|bibcode=1984PhRvB..30.1700F}}</ref> The ability of systems to use the zero-point field continuously as a source of energy or propellant is much more contentious (though peer-reviewed models have been proposed).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pinto|first1=F.|title=Engine cycle of an optically controlled vacuum energy transducer|journal=Phys. Rev. B|date=1999|volume=60|issue=21|pages=14740–14755|doi=10.1103/PhysRevB.60.14740|bibcode=1999PhRvB..6014740P}}</ref> There is debate over which formalisms of quantum mechanics apply to propulsion physics under such circumstances, the more refined [[Quantum Electrodynamics]] (QED), or the relatively undeveloped and controversial [[Stochastic electrodynamics|Stochastical Quantum Electrodynamics]] (SED).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Millis|first1=Marc G.|title=Progress in revolutionary propulsion physics|journal=61st International Astronautical Congress, Prague|date=2011|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/1101.1063v1.pdf|publisher=International Astronautical Federation|arxiv=1101.1063}}</ref> SED describes electromagnetic energy at absolute zero as a stochastic, fluctuating zero-point field. In SED the motion of a particle immersed in the stochastic zero-point radiation field generally results in highly nonlinear behaviour. Quantum effects emerge as a result of permanent matter-field interactions not possible to describe in QED<ref name="books.google.co.uk">{{cite journal|last1=Pena|first1=Luis de la|last2=Cetto|first2=Ana Maria|last3=Valdes-Hernandez|first3=Andrea|title=The Emerging Quantum: The Physics Behind Quantum Mechanics|date=2014|page=95|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-07893-9|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=v0MqBAAAQBAJ|isbn=9783319078939}}</ref> The typical mathematical models used in [[classical electromagnetism]], [[quantum electrodynamics]] (QED) and the [[standard model]] view electromagnetism as a U(1) gauge theory, which topologically restricts any complex nonlinear interaction. The [[QED vacuum|electromagnetic vacuum]] in these theories is generally viewed as a linear system with no overall observable consequence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Barrett|first1=Terence W.|title=Topological Foundations of Electromagnetism|date=2008|publisher=World Scientific|location=Singapore|isbn=9789812779977|page=2|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=e0-QdLqT-pIC}}</ref> For many practical calculations zero-point energy is dismissed by fiat in the mathematical model as a constant that may be canceled or as a term that has no physical effect.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Itzykson|first1=Claude|last2=Zuber|first2=Jean-Bernard|title=Quantum Field Theory|date=1980|publisher=McGraw-Hill|isbn=0070320713|pages=111}}</ref>
The 2016 NASA paper highlights that [[stochastic electrodynamics]] (SED) allows for a pilot-wave interpretation of quantum mechanics. Pilot-wave interpretations of quantum mechanics are a family of deterministic nonlocal theories distinct from other more mainstream interpretations such as the [[Copenhagen interpretation]] and [[Many-worlds interpretation|Everett's many-worlds interpretation]]. Pioneering experiments by Couder and Fort beginning in 2006<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Couder|first1=Yves|last2=Fort|first2=Emmanuel|title=Single-Particle Diffraction and Interference at a Macroscopic Scale|journal=Phys. Rev. Lett.|date=2006|volume=97|issue=15|page=154101|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.97.154101|url=http://users.isy.liu.se/en/jalar/kurser/QF/assignments/Couder2006.pdf|bibcode=2006PhRvL..97o4101C|pmid=17155330}}</ref> have shown that macroscopic classical pilot-waves can exhibit characteristics previously thought to be restricted to the quantum realm. Hydrodynamic pilot-wave analogs have been able to duplicate the double slit experiment, tunneling, quantized orbits, and numerous other quantum phenomena and as such pilot-wave theories are experiencing a resurgence in interest.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bush|first1=John W. M.|title=The new wave of pilot-wave theory|journal=Physics Today|date=2015|volume=68|issue=8|pages=47–53|doi=10.1063/PT.3.2882|url=http://newfos.arizona.edu/sites/default/files/uploads/documents/Pilot_Waves_Phys_Today_Aug_2015.pdf|bibcode=2015PhT....68h..47B}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bush|first1=John W. M.|title=Pilot-Wave Hydrodynamics|journal=Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics|date=2015|volume=47|pages=269–292|doi=10.1146/annurev-fluid-010814-014506|bibcode=2015AnRFM..47..269B|url=http://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/1721.1/89790/1/Bush_Pilot-wave.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wolchover|first1=Natalie|title=Fluid Tests Hint at Concrete Quantum Reality|journal=Quanta Magazine|date=June 24, 2014|url=https://www.quantamagazine.org/20140624-fluid-tests-hint-at-concrete-quantum-reality/|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Falk|first1=Dan|title=New Support for Alternative Quantum View|journal=Quanta Magazine|date=May 16, 2016|url=https://www.quantamagazine.org/20160517-pilot-wave-theory-gains-experimental-support/|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref> Coulder and Fort note in their 2006 paper that pilot-waves are nonlinear dissipative systems sustained by external forces. A dissipative system is characterized by the spontaneous appearance of symmetry breaking ([[anisotropy]]) and the formation of complex, sometimes [[Chaos theory|chaotic]] or [[Emergence|emergent]], dynamics where interacting fields can exhibit long range correlations. In SED the [[zero point field]] (ZPF) plays the role of the pilot wave that guides real particles on their way. Modern approaches to SED consider wave and particle-like quantum effects as well-coordinated emergent systems that are the result of speculated sub-quantum interactions with the zero-point field<ref name="books.google.co.uk"/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Grössing|first1=G.|last2=Fussy|first2=S.|last3=Mesa Pascasio|first3=J.|last4=Schwabl|first4=H.|title=An explanation of interference effects in the double slit experiment: Classical trajectories plus ballistic diffusion caused by zero-point fluctuations|journal=Annals of Physics|date=2012|volume=327|issue=2|pages=421–437|doi=10.1016/j.aop.2011.11.010|url=https://arxiv.org/pdf/1106.5994.pdf|arxiv=1106.5994|bibcode=2012AnPhy.327..421G}}</ref><ref name="The Quantum as an Emergent System">{{cite journal|last1=Grössing|first1=G.|last2=Fussy|first2=S.|last3=Mesa Pascasio|first3=J.|last4=Schwabl|first4=H.|title=The Quantum as an Emergent System|journal=Journal of Physics: Conference Series|date=2012|volume=361|issue=1|page=012008|doi=10.1088/1742-6596/361/1/012008|url=http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1742-6596/361/1/012008/pdf|arxiv=1205.3393}}</ref>
=== Controversy and criticism === Some notable physicists have found the Q-thruster concept to be implausible. For example, mathematical physicist [[John Baez]] has criticized the reference to "quantum vacuum virtual plasma" noting that: "There's no such thing as 'virtual plasma' ".<ref>https://plus.google.com/117663015413546257905/posts/WfFtJ8bYVya</ref> Noted Caltech theoretical physicist [[Sean M. Carroll]] has also affirmed this statement, writing "[t]here is no such thing as a ‘quantum vacuum virtual plasma,’...".<ref>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/outthere/2014/08/06/nasa-validate-imposible-space-drive-word/#.VCYphStdU3c</ref> In addition, Lafleur found that [[quantum field theory]] predicts no net force, implying that the measured thrusts are unlikely to be due to quantum effects. However, Lafleur noted that this conclusion was based on the assumption that the electric and magnetic fields were homogeneous, whereas certain theories posit a small net force in inhomogeneous vacuums.<ref>{{cite arXiv|eprint=1411.5359 |title=Can the quantum vacuum be used as a reaction medium to generate thrust? |date=2014-11-19 |last1=Lafleur |first1=Trevor |class=quant-ph }}</ref>
Notably, the violation of energy and momentum conservation laws have been heavily criticized. In a presentation at Nasa Ames Research Centre in November 2014, Harold White addressed the issue of conservation of momentum by stating that the Q-thruster conserves momentum by creating a wake or anisotropic state in the quantum vacuum. White indicated that once false positives were ruled out, Eagleworks would explore the momentum distribution and divergence angle of the quantum vacuum wake using a second Q-thruster to measure the quantum vacuum wake.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wokn7crjBbA</ref> In a paper published in January 2014, White proposed to address the conservation of momentum issue by stating that the Q-thruster pushes quantum particles (electrons/positrons) in one direction, whereas the Q-thruster recoils to conserve momentum in the other direction. White stated that this principle was similar to how a submarine uses its propeller to push water in one direction, while the submarine recoils to conserve momentum.<ref>https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20140013174.pdf</ref> Hence, the violations of fundamental laws of physics can be avoided.
=== Other hypothesized quantum vacuum thrusters === A number of physicists have suggested that a spacecraft or object may generate thrust through its interaction with the quantum vacuum. For example, Fabrizio Pinto in a 2006 paper published in the ''[[Journal of the British Interplanetary Society]]'' noted it may be possible to bring a cluster of polarisable vacuum particles to a hover in the laboratory and then to transfer thrust to a macroscopic accelerating vehicle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jbis.org.uk/paper.php?p=2006.59.247 |title=Progress in Quantum Vacuum Engineering Propulsion |publisher=JBIS |date= |accessdate=2014-08-04}}</ref> Similarly, Jordan Maclay in a 2004 paper titled "A Gedanken Spacecraft that Operates Using the Quantum Vacuum (Dynamic Casimir Effect)" published in the [[scientific journal]] ''[[Foundations of Physics]]'' noted that it is possible to accelerate a spacecraft based on the dynamic [[Casimir effect]], in which [[electromagnetic radiation]] is emitted when an uncharged mirror is properly accelerated in vacuum.<ref>{{Cite journal |title=A Gedanken Spacecraft that Operates Using the Quantum Vacuum (Dynamic Casimir Effect) |journal=Foundations of Physics |volume=34 |issue=3 |pages=477–500 |date=2004-03-01 |arxiv=physics/0303108 |bibcode=2004FoPh...34..477M |author1=MacLay |first1=G. Jordan |last2=Forward |first2=Robert L. |doi=10.1023/B:FOOP.0000019624.51662.50 }}</ref> Similarly, Puthoff noted in a 2010 paper titled "Engineering the Zero-Point Field and Polarizable Vacuum For Interstellar Flight" published in the ''Journal of the British Interplanetary Society'' noted that it may be possible that the quantum vacuum might be manipulated so as to provide energy/thrust for future space vehicles.<ref name=Puthoff>{{Cite journal|arxiv=1012.5264 |title=Engineering the Zero-Point Field and Polarizable Vacuum For Interstellar Flight |journal=J.Br.Interplanet.Soc |volume=55 |pages=137–144 |date=2010-12-23 |last1= Puthoff |first1=H. E. |last2= Little |first2=S. R. |bibcode = 2010arXiv1012.5264P }}</ref> Likewise, researcher Yoshinari Minami in a 2008 paper titled "Preliminary Theoretical Considerations for Getting Thrust via Squeezed Vacuum" published in the ''Journal of the British Interplanetary Society'' noted the theoretical possibility of extracting thrust from the excited vacuum induced by controlling squeezed light.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jbis.org.uk/paper.php?p=2008.61.315 |title=Preliminary Theorectical Considerations for Getting Thrust via Squeezed Vacuum |publisher=JBIS |date= |accessdate=2014-08-04}}</ref> In addition, Alexander Feigel in a 2009 paper noted that propulsion in [[quantum vacuum]] may be achieved by rotating or aggregating magneto-electric [[nano-particle]]s in strong perpendicular electrical and magnetic fields.<ref>{{cite arXiv|eprint=0912.1031 |title=A magneto-electric quantum wheel |date=2009-12-05 |last1=Feigel |first1=Alexander |class=quant-ph }}</ref>
However, according to Puthoff,<ref name=Puthoff/> although this method can produce angular momentum causing a static disk (known as a Feynman disk) to begin to rotate,<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v285/n5761/abs/285154a0.html |title=Observation of static electromagnetic angular momentum in vacua |publisher=Nature Publishing Group |date= |accessdate=2014-08-09 |volume=285 |issue=5761 |doi=10.1038/285154a0 |journal=Nature |pages=154–155|bibcode=1980Natur.285..154G |year=1980 |last1=Graham |first1=G. M |last2=Lahoz |first2=D. G }}</ref> it cannot induce linear momentum due to a phenomenon known as "hidden momentum" that cancels the ability of the proposed E×B propulsion method to generate linear momentum.<ref>{{Cite journal|url=http://scitation.aip.org/content/aapt/journal/ajp/65/1/10.1119/1.18500 |title=Hidden momentum of a relativistic fluid carrying current in an external electric field |journal=American Journal of Physics |volume=65 |pages=92 |publisher=AIP Publishing |date=1997 |accessdate=2014-08-09|doi=10.1119/1.18500 |last1=Hnizdo |first1=V. |bibcode=1997AmJPh..65...92H }}</ref> However, some recent experimental and theoretical work by van Tiggelen and colleagues suggests that linear momentum may be transferred from the quantum vacuum in the presence of an external magnetic field.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Transfer of linear momentum from the quantum vacuum to a magnetochiral molecule|volume=1404|issue=21|pages=5990|arxiv=1404.5990|bibcode=2015JPCM...27u4002D|last1=Donaire|first1=Manuel|last2=Van Tiggelen|first2=Bart|last3=Rikken|first3=Geert|year=2014|doi=10.1088/0953-8984/27/21/214002|journal=Journal of Physics: Condensed Matter}}</ref>
== Experiments == In 2013, the [[Advanced Propulsion Physics Laboratory|Eagleworks]] team tested a device called the Serrano Field Effect Thruster, built by Gravitec Inc. at the request of [[Boeing]] and [[DARPA]]. The Eagleworks team has theorized that this device is a Q-thruster.<ref name="Warp Field Physics 2013">{{cite journal|last1=White|first1=Harold|title=Eagleworks Laboratories: Warp Field Physics|journal=Nasa Technical Reports Server (NTRS)|date=2013|volume=20140000851|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20140000851.pdf}}</ref> The thruster consists of a set of circular dielectrics sandwiched between electrodes; its inventor describes it device as producing thrust through a preselected shaping of an electric field.<ref>{{cite web|title=Propulsion device and method employing electric fields for producing thrust|url=http://www.google.com/patents/US6492784}}</ref> Gravitec Inc. alleges that in 2011 they tested the "asymmetrical capacitor" device in a high vacuum several times and have ruled out ion wind or electrostatic forces as an explanation for the thrust produced.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gravitec Inc. Website |url=http://gravitecinc.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130604233553/http://gravitecinc.com/ |archivedate=4 June 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In February through June 2013, the Eagleworks team evaluated the SFE test article in and out of a Faraday Shield and at various vacuum conditions.<ref name="Warp Field Physics 2013" /> Thrust was observed in the ~1–20 N/kW range. The magnitude of the thrust scaled approximately with the cube of the input voltage (20–110 μN).<ref>{{cite web|title=Eagleworks Newsletter 2013|url=https://xa.yimg.com/kq/groups/86787010/513081407/name/Eagleworks+Newsletter+2013.pdf}}</ref> As of 2015, the researchers have not published a peer-reviewed paper detailing the results of this experiment.
Using a [[torsion pendulum]], [[Harold G. White (NASA)|White's]] team claimed to have measured 30–50 ''μ''N of thrust from a [[Microwave cavity|microwave cavity resonator]] designed by Guido Fetta in an attempt at propellant-less propulsion. Using the same measurement equipment, a non-zero force was also measured on a "null" resonator that was not designed to experience any such force, which they suggest hints at "interaction with the quantum vacuum virtual plasma".<ref>{{cite web|title=Anomalous Thrust Production from an RF Test Device Measured on a Low-Thrust Torsion Pendulum |url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20140006052.pdf}}</ref> All measurements were performed at atmospheric pressure, presumably in contact with air, and with no analysis of systematic errors, except for the use of an RF load without the resonant cavity interior as a control device.<ref>http://arc.aiaa.org/doi/abs/10.2514/6.2014-4029</ref> In early 2015, Paul March from that team made new results public, claiming positive experimental force measurements with a torsional pendulum in a hard vacuum: about 50 µN with 50 W of input power at 5.0×10<sup>−6</sup> [[torr]], and new null-thrust tests.<ref name="NBF_20150206">{{cite web |title=Update on EMDrive work at NASA Eagleworks |website=NextBigFuture |author=Wang, Brian |date=6 February 2015 |url=http://nextbigfuture.com/2015/02/update-on-emdrive-work-at-nasa.html }}</ref> The claims of the team have not yet been published in a peer-reviewed journal, only as a conference paper in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Anomalous Thrust Production from an RF Test Device Measured on a Low-Thrust Torsion Pendulum|url=http://www.libertariannews.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/AnomalousThrustProductionFromanRFTestDevice-BradyEtAl.pdf}}</ref>
Yu Zhu previously claimed to have measured anomalous thrust arising from a similar device, using power levels roughly 100 times greater, and measuring thrust roughly 1000 times greater.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|title=The Performance Analysis of Microwave Thrust without Propellant Based on the Quantum Theory|url=http://en.cnki.com.cn/Article_en/CJFDTOTAL-YHXB200805027.htm}}</ref>
=== Current experiments === [[File:Woodward Effect Device.png|thumb|right|The 2006 [[Woodward effect]] test article]] [[File:Woodward Effect Results.png|thumb|right|Plot diagram of the 2006 [[Woodward effect]] test results]] As of 2015, Eagleworks is attempting to gather performance data to support the development of a Q-thruster engineering prototype for [[reaction control system|reaction-control-system]] applications in the force range of 0.1–1 N with a corresponding input electrical power range of 0.3–3 kW. The group plans to begin by testing a refurbished test article to improve the historical performance of a 2006 experiment that attempted to demonstrate the [[Woodward effect]]. The photograph shows the test article and the plot diagram shows the thrust trace from a 500g load cell in experiments performed in 2006.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=March|first1=P.|last2=Palfreyman|first2=A.|title=The Woodward Effect: Math Modeling and Continued Experimental Verifications at 2 to 4 MHz| journal=Proceedings of Space Technology and Applications International Forum (STAIF)|volume=813|pages=1321|year=2006|editor=M. S. El-Genk|publisher=American Institute of Physics, Melville, New York|url=http://proceedings.aip.org/resource/2/apcpcs/813/1/1321_1|accessdate=29 January 2013|bibcode=2006AIPC..813.1321M|doi=10.1063/1.2169317}}</ref>
The group hopes that testing the device on a high-fidelity torsion pendulum (1–4 μN at 10–40 W) will unambiguously demonstrate the feasibility of this concept. The team is maintaining a dialogue with the [[International Space Station|ISS national labs office]] for an on-orbit [[International Space Station#Scientific research|detailed test objective]] (DTO) to test the Q-thrusters operation in the vacuum and weightlessness of outer space.<ref name=NASA>{{cite web|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20110023492_2011024705.pdf|title=Eagleworks Laboratories: Advanced Propulsion Physics Research|date=2 December 2011|accessdate=10 January 2013|publisher=NASA}}</ref>

'''Real-time data''' ('''RTD''') is information that is delivered immediately after collection. There is no delay in the timeliness of the information provided. Real-time data is often used for navigation or tracking.<ref>Wade, T. and Sommer, S. eds. ''[http://store.esri.com/esri/showdetl.cfm?SID=2&Product_ID=868&Category_ID=49 A to Z GIS]''</ref> Such data is usually [[data processing|processed]] using [[real-time computing]] although it can also be stored for later or off-line [[data analysis]].
Real-time data is not the same as [[dynamic data]]. Real-time data can be dynamic (e.g. a variable indicating current location) or static (e.g. a fresh log entry indicating location at a specific time).
==In economics== Real-time economic data, and other [[official statistics]], are often based on preliminary estimates, and therefore are frequently adjusted as better estimates become available. These later adjusted data are called "[[Official statistics#Data revision|revised data]]". The terms real-time economic data and real-time economic analysis were coined<ref>Dean Croushore (2011), '[http://pubs.aeaweb.org/doi/pdfplus/10.1257/jel.49.1.72 Frontiers of Real-Time Data Analysis]'. ''Journal of Economic Literature'' 49 (1), pp. 72-100.</ref> by Francis X. Diebold and Glenn D. Rudebusch.<ref>Francis X. Diebold and Glenn D. Rudebusch (1991), 'Forecasting Output with the Composite Leading Index: A Real-Time Analysis'. ''Journal of the American Statistical Association'' 86 (415), pp. 603–10.</ref> [[Macroeconomics|Macroeconomist]] Glenn D. Rudebusch defined real-time analysis as 'the use of sequential information sets that were actually available as history unfolded.'<ref>Glenn D. Rudebusch (2002), '[http://www.frbsf.org/economic-research/economists/grudebusch/Rudebusch_EJ2002.pdf Assessing Nominal Income Rules for Monetary Policy with Model and Data Uncertainty]'. ''Economic Journal'' 112 (479), pp. 402–32</ref> Macroeconomist [[Athanasios Orphanides]] has argued that economic policy rules may have very different effects when based on error-prone real-time data (as they inevitably are in reality) than they would if policy makers followed the same rules but had more accurate data available.<ref>A. Orphanides and J.C. Williams (2006), '[http://econpapers.repec.org/paper/fipfedgfe/2005-51.htm Monetary Policy under Imperfect Knowledge]'. ''Journal of the European Economic Association'' 4 (2-3), pp. 366-375.</ref>
In order to better understand the accuracy of economic data and its effects on economic decisions, some economic organizations, such as the [[Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis]], [[Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia]] and the Euro-Area Business Cycle Network (EABCN), have made databases available that contain both real-time data and subsequent revised estimates of the same data.
==In auctions== [[Real-time bidding]] is programmatic real-time auctions that sell digital-ad impressions. Entities on both the buying and selling sides require almost instantaneous access to data in order to make decisions, forcing real-time data to the forefront of their needs.<ref>Rodgers, A. [http://econsultancy.com/blog/64088-publishers-embrace-real-time-bidding-as-data-takes-centre-stage-new-report, Publishers embrace real-time bidding as data takes centre stage: new report], 8 January 2014</ref> To support these needs, new strategies and technologies, such [[Druid (open-source data store)|Druid]] have arisen and are quickly evolving.<ref>Lorica, B. [http://strata.oreilly.com/2013/08/big-data-and-advertising.html Big Data and Advertising: In the trenches], 4 August 2013</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = Rosetta Genomics | logo = | type = [[Public company|Public]] ({{NASDAQ|ROSG}}) | genre = | foundation = 2000 | founder = Dr. Isaac Bentwich | location_city = [[Rehovot]], [[Israel]] and [[Jersey City]], [[United States|U.S.]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = Ken Berlin ([[President (corporate title)|President]] and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]])
Dr. Isaac Bentwich ([[Entrepreneur|Founder]]) | industry = [[Biotechnology]] | products = [[microRNA]]-based diagnostic tests and therapeutics | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 70 (as of 2008) | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.rosettagenomics.com/ www.rosettagenomics.com] | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Rosetta Genomics Ltd.''' is a molecular [[diagnostics]] company with offices in Israel and the United States that uses micro-ribonucleic acid ([[microRNA]]) [[biomarker]]s to develop diagnostic tests designed to differentiate between various types of [[cancer]].Chambers, Heather. "Isis, Alnylam Pair To Seek Disease-Fighting Drugs." ''San Diego Business Journal'', September 17, 2007. The company expects the first three tests based on its technology to be submitted for regulatory approval in 2008."Columbia University Medical Center and Rosetta Genomics Announce Columbia University's Submission of the First Cancer Diagnostic Test Based on Rosetta Genomics Proprietary MicroRNA Technology for Approval to the New York State Department of Health Clinical Laboratory Evaluation Program," Forbes.com, April 3, 2008 The diagnostic tests will differentiate between [[squamous]] and non-squamous [[non-small cell lung cancer]] (NSCLC); differentiate between [[adenocarcinoma]] and [[peritoneal mesothelioma]];"Rosetta Genomics Ltd. Completes Prevalidation Phase for First Diagnostic Production." ''Reuters'', October 30, 2007. and seek to identify the origin of [[tumors]] in patients representing [[cancer of unknown primary]] (CUP).Boggs, Jennifer. "Rosetta Genomics' IPO Raising $26.3M For MicroRNA Work."''BioWorld Today'', February 28, 2007. Using a single microRNA, the highly sensitive, highly specific test for squamous and non-squamous lung cancer has passed the prevalidation phase and has been submitted for approval to the New York State Department of Health Clinical Laboratory Evaluation Program in April 2008. In April 2008, ''[[Nature Biotechnology]]'' published a study by Rosetta Genomics’ scientists whose findings demonstrate microRNAs' significant potential to act as effective biomarkers that may be applied in a diagnostic test designed to identify the primary tumor site in patients CUP.{{cite journal |vauthors=Rosenfeld N, Aharonov R, Meiri E, etal |title=MicroRNAs accurately identify cancer tissue origin |journal=Nat. Biotechnol. |volume=26 |issue=4 |pages=462–9 |date=April 2008 |pmid=18362881 |doi=10.1038/nbt1392 |url=http://www.nature.com/nbt/journal/v26/n4/pdf/nbt1392.pdf|format=PDF}} In addition to its diagnostic programs, Rosetta Genomics is collaborating with Isis Pharmaceuticals to develop a microRNA-based therapy for [[Hepatocellular carcinoma]] (HCC), a form of [[liver cancer]]."Antisense Oligonucleotide, Heptacellular carcinoma, Isis/Rosetta Genomics Isis, Rosetta Genomics Licensing Agreement." ''R&D Focus Drug News'', March 6, 2006. ==Intellectual property== Rosetta Genomics has developed a [[microRNA]] discovery process. {{cite journal |vauthors=Bentwich I, Avniel A, Karov Y, etal |title=Identification of hundreds of conserved and nonconserved human microRNAs |journal=Nat. Genet. |volume=37 |issue=7 |pages=766–70 |date=July 2005 |pmid=15965474 |doi=10.1038/ng1590 |url=http://www.nature.com/ng/journal/v37/n7/pdf/ng1590.pdf|format=PDF}} ==Platform technologies== Rosetta Genomics has developed several proprietary technologies that enable the Company to work with microRNAs. At the basis of these technologies are proprietary [[microRNA]] extraction protocols that include sensitive extraction of microRNAs from most body fluids, including serum, urine, saliva, with virtually no microRNA lost in the extraction process."Other News To Note," ''Bioworld Today'', April 3, 2007. The company has also developed a microRNA extraction protocol from Formalin Fixed Paraffin Embedded, or FFPE, samples. This allows extraction of microRNAs from samples preserved at room temperature."Henry Ford Hospital and Rosetta Genomics To Develop MicroRNA-based Diagnostics For Brain Cancer," ''Company Reports'', January 14, 2008. Once microRNAs are extracted, Rosetta Genomics’ technology is capable of detecting and quantifying the microRNAs using two custom designed platform technologies which utilize Quantitative Real Time PCR (or qRT-PCR) and microarrays."Nanogen, Inc. Licenses MGB Probe Technology To Rosetta Genomics, Ltd.," ''Reuters Significant Developments'', December 11, 2007. The Company’s proprietary microarray platform covers approximately 850 human microRNAs, including approximately 180 microRNAs "Rosetta and Rockefeller Enter MicroRNA Agreement," ''Datamonitor News and Comment'', June 16, 2006. which are Rosetta Genomics’ proprietary microRNAs. The array’s high specificity allows discriminating homologous family members. ==Licenses and collaborations== In January 2008, Rosetta Genomics announced a collaboration agreement with the [[Henry Ford Health System]] in Detroit, Michigan to develop [[microRNA]]-based diagnostics and prognostics for [[brain cancer]]."Business Diary: Acquisitions," ''Crain's Detroit Business'', February 25, 2008. Also in January 2008, Rosetta Genomics announced that its subsidiary, Rosetta Genomics Inc. has received a license to use Roche Molecular Systems' [[PCR]] technology in microRNA-based diagnostic tests.http://www.fdanews.com/newsletter/article?articleId=102868&issueId=11189 "Rosetta Genomics Licenses Roche PCR Technology", ''FDAnews Device Daily Bulletin'', January 9, 2008 In September 2007, Rosetta Genomics said it will work with [[New York University]] Medical Center to develop a microRNA-based diagnostic test for [[melanoma]].Everitt, Jay. "Rosetta Genomics, Ltd--ROSG: To Work In Collaboration With NYU Medical Center," ''Knobias'', September 7, 2007. In May 2007, Rosetta Genomics announced [[Columbia University Medical Center]] would utilize its [[Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments]] (CLIA)-certified laboratory to perform the clinical validation of Rosetta Genomics’ diagnostics program for cancer of unknown primary."Rosetta Genomics Ltd. Signs Agreement With Columbia University Medical center," ''Reuters'', May 21, 2007. In February 2006, Isis Pharmaceuticals Inc. and Rosetta Genomics said they will collaborate to develop [[antisense drugs]] that inhibit microRNA in the liver to treat cancers there. Antisense drugs are a class of compounds that interfere with genetic material that gets translated into harmful proteins."Isis, Rosetta Join On Cancer Treatment," ''Associated Press'', February 22, 2006. ==History== Rosetta Genomics was founded by Isaac Bentwich in 2000 https://www.forbes.com/business/forbes/2005/1212/092.html Herper, Matthew and Robert Langreth. "Treasures In The Trash," ''Forbes'', December 12, 2005. to pursue commercial applications of [[microRNA]] research. http://www.hoovers.com/rosetta-genomics/--ID__153400--/free-co-profile.xhtml Hoovers Web site; "Rosetta Genomics Company Description." The company had its [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]] on March 6, 2007 and is traded on the [[NASDAQ]]."Alnylam Pharma Shares Rise On Cantor Fitgerald's microRNA Technology Outlook," ''Associated Press'', September 11, 2007. Rosetta Genomics expects the funds raised to advance its microRNA-based diagnostic and therapeutic cancer products through initial clinical validation, defined as success in identifying the specific biomarker panels via blinded tests of samples supplied by medical institutions. In 2016, the company was ranked #27 on the [[Deloitte Fast 500#Fast 500 North America| Deloitte Fast 500 North America]] list.{{cite web|url=https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/us/Documents/technology-media-telecommunications/us-tmt-2016-fast-500-winners-by-rank.pdf|title=2016 Winners by rank|publisher=[[Deloitte]]|accessdate=14 October 2017}} On 31 May, 2018, it was announced that Rosetta Genomics filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy.[https://www.genomeweb.com/molecular-diagnostics/rosetta-genomics-files-chapter-7-bankruptcy Rosetta Genomics Files for Chapter 7 Bankruptcy] {{Subscription required}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.rosettagenomics.com/ Company website] {{Israel NASDAQ}} [[Category:Biotechnology companies]] [[Category:Biotechnology companies established in 2000]] [[Category:Biotechnology companies disestablished in 2018]] [[Category:Biotechnology companies of Israel]] [[Category:Companies listed on NASDAQ]] [[Category:Genomics companies]] [[Category:Companies that have filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy]]

The '''SCR-203''' was a [[U.S. Army]] [[radio]] [[transceiver]] used during [[World War II]] and designed to be mounted on an animal [[pack saddle]]. <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:SCR-203 radio.jpg|thumb|250px|title|SCR-203 pack radio 1943]] -->
==Specifications== The SCR-203 was a low power, short range, portable command set designed to clamp onto a Phillips pack saddle for animal-pack transportation and operation. It was used primarily by the [[cavalry]], and [[field artillery]]. It consisted of the BC-228 transmitter, the BC-227 receiver, and BC-235 control box and could transmit 7.5 [[watt]]s [[Amplitude modulation|AM]] voice, [[Modulated continuous wave|MCW]], or [[Continuous wave|CW]] for a range of approximately 30 [[miles]]. Its [[radio frequency]] coverage was approximately 2.0 to 3.0 [[Mhz]]. The unit was powered by various battery packs and a GN-35 hand cranked [[wiktionary:Generator|generator]] and used a 25 ft whip [[Antenna (radio)|antenna]].
==History== The [[mule]]-packed radio concept dates back to before [[World War I]], but due to the decline of the Horse Cavalry and the miniaturization of radio components, the SCR-203 was the last of the U.S. Army's radio sets designed to be animal-mounted. The SCR-203 was replaced by the [[SCR-245]].

'''Saskia Van Uffelen''' is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] business woman, active in the ICT field, and involved in activities related to the skills impact of digital transformation.
== Biography == She started her career in the IT sector in 1984, held several roles in IT companies ([[Xerox]], [[Compaq]], [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]] and Arinso), became CEO of Bull & CSB Consulting in 2008, and is CEO of Ericsson Belux since 2014.
She holds positions <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zonebourse.com/barons-bourse/Saskia-van-Uffelen-06X9ZC-E/biographie/|title=Saskia van Uffelen - Biographie|last=Bourse|first=Zone|website=www.zonebourse.com|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref>on the board of Belgian postal company bpost SA, High voltage company [[Elia System Operator]] SA, Elia Asset SA, and insurance company [[AXA]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://press.axa.be/chantal-de-vrieze-en-saskia-van-uffelen-versterken-de-raad-van-bestuur-van-axa-belgium-als-onafhankelijke-bestuurders|title=Chantal De Vrieze en Saskia Van Uffelen versterken de raad van bestuur van AXA Belgium als onafhankelijke bestuurders|access-date=2018-10-13|language=nl-BE}}</ref>
Her public interventions, (e.g. [[TED (conference)|TEDx events]])<ref>{{Citation|last=TEDx Talks|title=Dare to Disrupt {{!}} Saskia Van Uffelen {{!}} TEDxUHasselt|date=2017-05-11|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y-lbwgf4u-4|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref> focus on embracing the digital and organisational change whilst putting the human factor in the centre.
In 2012, as part of the European DigitalChampions initiative,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/digital-champion-belgium|title=Saskia Van Uffelen|work=Digital Single Market|access-date=2018-10-13|language=en}}</ref> Belgium nominated<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://economie.fgov.be/fr/themes/line/agenda-numerique-pour-leurope/digital-champion|title=Digital Champion {{!}} SPF Economie|website=economie.fgov.be|language=fr|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref> her to be part of the Digital Champion expert Group. Her focus is on improving ICT skills.
In 2014 she started the coordination of the Belgian coalition on digital skills and jobs, part of the European coalition on digital skills and jobs<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/national-local-coalitions|title=National Coalitions|work=Digital Single Market|access-date=2018-10-13|language=en}}</ref> and launched the official Federal Belgian initiative digitalchampion.be.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://digitalbelgium.be/fr/alexander-de-croo-et-saskia-van-uffelen-lancent-digitalchampions-be/|title=Alexander De Croo et Saskia Van Uffelen lancent DigitalChampions.be – Digital Belgium|website=digitalbelgium.be|language=fr|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref>
In 2017 she became part of the European Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition Governing Board,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ec.europa.eu/digital-single-market/en/governing-board-digital-skills-and-jobs-coalition|title=The Governing Board of the Digital Skills and Jobs Coalition|work=Digital Single Market|access-date=2018-10-13|language=en}}</ref> overseeing the national coalitions on digital skills.
She became member of the Digital minds for Belgium,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://digitalbelgium.be/digital-minds/|title=Digital Minds – Digital Belgium|website=digitalbelgium.be|language=nl|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref> an informal advisory body of the Belgian Governement related to digital initiatives.
In 2017 she became co-founder of Becentral,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.becentral.org/cofounders.html|title=Co-founders & Ambassadors|website=www.becentral.org|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref> an initiative aimed at digital transformation of the Belgian society.
== Awards ==
* Member of Hogenheuvelcollege, 2010,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.smartbiz.be/article/122154/saskia-van-uffelen-devient-membre-du-hogenheuvelcollege/|title=Saskia Van Uffelen devient membre du Hogenheuvelcollege {{!}} Smart Business|date=2010-11-12|work=Smart Business|access-date=2018-10-13|language=en-US}}</ref> honorary distinction towards enterprise people from the university [[KULeuven]] * ICT Women of the year by Datanews in 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://datanews.levif.be/ict/actualite/saskia-van-uffelen-a-la-tete-d-ericsson-belux/article-normal-293829.html|title=Saskia Van Uffelen à la tête d'Ericsson Belux|date=2014-04-02|access-date=2018-10-13}}</ref> * The association Flanders-Europa awarded her the medal for economic achievement in 2016.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.vlaandereneuropa.net/gulden-spoor/|title=Gulden Spoor - Beweging Vlaanderen - Europa|work=Beweging Vlaanderen - Europa|access-date=2018-10-13|language=nl-NL}}</ref>
== Author == She published the management book "Iedereen baas" (in [[Dutch language|Dutch]] language)<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/879572436|title=Iedereen baas! : over samenwerken met vier generaties|last=Saskia.|first=Van Uffelen,|isbn=9789401416832|location=Leuven|oclc=879572436}}</ref> or "Tous patron"<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/898034929|title=Tous "patron" ! : de la coopération entre quatre générations cop. 2013|last=Saskia.|first=Van Uffelen,|date=|publisher=Lannoo Campus|isbn=9789401419871|location=Bruxelles|oclc=898034929}}</ref> about the fact that 4 generations ([[generation X]], [[Millennials|generation Y]], [[generation Z]] [[Baby boomers|babyboomers]]) of employees have to work together on the workfloor.
She is also co-author of the book "social technologies in business: connect share, lead" <ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/990142134|title=Social Technologies in Business: Connect, Share, Lead.|last=De.|first=Clercq, Isabel|isbn=9782874034725|location=[Place of publication not identified]|oclc=990142134}}</ref> on how social technologies are transforming organisations.
== References == <references />

'''Sidney Leavitt Pressey''' ([[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], December 28, 1888 – July 1, 1979) was Professor of [[Psychology]] at [[Ohio State University]] for many years. He is famous for having invented a [[teaching machine]] many years before the idea became popular.
:"The first.. [teaching machine] was developed by Sidney L. Pressey... While originally developed as a self-scoring machine... [it] demonstrated its ability to actually teach".<ref name=H&B>Hilgard E.R. & Bower G.H. 1966. ''Theories of learning''. 3rd ed, New York:Appleton-Century-Crofts. Chapter 16: Learning & the technology of instruction, 554{{ndash}}561 Programmed learning.</ref>
Pressey joined Ohio State in 1921, and stayed there until he retired in 1959. He continued publishing after retirement, with 18 papers between 1959 and 1967.<ref name=Lorin>Anderson, Lorin W. 2002. Pressey, Sidney L. (1888–1979). In ''Encyclopedia of Education''. [http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-3403200497.html]</ref> He was a [[cognitive psychology|cognitive psychologist]] who "rejected a view of learning as an accumulation of responses governed by environmental stimuli in favor of one governed by meaning, intention, and purpose".<ref name=Lorin/> In fact, he had been a cognitive psychologist his entire life, well before the "mythical birthday of the cognitive revolution in psychology".<ref>Bruner, Jerome S. 1992. Another look at New Look 1. ''American Psychologist''. '''47''', 780–783.</ref>
== The 'teaching machine' == Pressey's idea started as a machine for administering [[multiple-choice]] questions (MCQs) to students. MCQs were (and are still) a basic method for testing students in the United States. Pressey's machine had a window with a question and four answers. The student pressed the key to the chosen answer. The machine recorded the answer on a counter to the back of the machine, and showed the next question.
The great idea was to fix the machine so that it would not move on until the student chose the right answer. Then it was easy to show that this second arrangement taught the students which were the right answers. This was the first demonstration that a machine could teach, and also a demonstration that [[knowledge of results]] was the cause of the learning.<ref>Pressey S.L. 1926. A simple apparatus which gives tests and scores {{ndash}} and teaches. ''School and Society'', '''23''' (586), 373–376.</ref><ref>Pressey S.L. 1927. A machine for automatic teaching of drill material. ''School and Society'', '''25''' (645), 549–552.</ref><ref>Pressey S.L. 1932. A third and fourth contribution toward the coming "industrial revolution" in education. ''School and Society'', '''36''' (934), 668–672.</ref> This kind of feedback to the learner is basic: it just tells the learner whether they are right or not. Later work on other kinds of learning material showed that even better results were got when the feedback contained more explanatory material.<ref>Lumsdaine A.A. 1965. Experimental results on instructional devices and materials. In Glaser R. (ed) ''Training research and education''. New York: Wiley, especially 258–266.</ref><ref>Annett J. 1964. The role of knowledge of results in learning: a survey. In ''Educational Technology'', De Cecco (ed), Holt, Rinehart & Winston, 279–285.</ref>
Pressey continued to improve his devices after [[World War II]],<ref>Pressey 1950. Development and appraisal of devices providing immediate automatic scoring of objective tests and concomitant self instruction. ''Journal of Psychology'', '''29''', 417–447.</ref> and the papers of Pressey and his colleagues are reprinted in a leading sourcebook.<ref name=TMPL/>
A number of reviews credit Pressey with being the originator of teaching machines, and of important aspects of [[programmed learning]]. This was long before the better known efforts of [[B.F. Skinner]].<ref name=Lums>Lumsdaine A.A. 1963. Instruments and media of instruction. In N.L. Gage (ed) ''Handbook of research on teaching''. Chicago: AERA and Rand McNally, 592 (auto-instructional methods), 620 (differential feedback).</ref><ref name=TMPL>Lumsdaine A.A & Glaser R. (eds) 1960. ''Teaching machines and programmed learning: a source book''. Washington D.C. National Education Association.</ref><ref>Crowder N. 1959. Automatic tutoring by means of intrinsic programming. In Galanter E.H. (ed) ''Automatic teaching: the state of the art''. New York: Wiley, 109–116.</ref> The review by Klaus gave a special appreciation of Pressey and his work.<ref>Klaus D.J. 1965. Analysis of programming techniques. In Glaser R. (ed) ''Teaching machines and programmed learning II: data and directions''. Washington D.C. Department of Audiovisual Instruction, National Education Association, 144–147.</ref> Skinner, who was responsible for bringing the whole subject into popular view, acknowledged Pressey's work in his 1958 paper on teaching machines.<ref>Skinner B.F. 1958. Teaching machines. ''Science'' '''128''', 969–977, reprinted in Skinner 1965.</ref><ref>Skinner B.F. 1965. ''The technology of teaching''. Appleton-Century-Croft. Includes reprints of Skinner's earlier papers on programmed learning, and discusses the limitations of classroom teaching in several places, such as chapter 5 Why teachers fail, and chapter 10 A review of teaching.</ref>
Pressey's own term was "adjunct autoinstruction". He thought it important to follow learning by questions "to enhance the clarity and stability of cognitive structure by correcting misapprehensions, and deferring the instruction of new matter until there had been such clarification and elucidation".<ref>Pressey S.L. 1951. Teaching machines (and learning theory) crisis. ''J. Applied Psychology'' '''47''', 1-6.</ref> The topic itself might be programmed, or it might not.<ref>Pressey S.L. 1964. Auto elucidation without programming. ''NSPI Journal'' '''3''', 12-13.</ref>
== Pressey's major textbook == Pressey's major textbook ''Psychology and the new education'', 1937 and 1944,<ref>Pressey S.L. 1933. ''Psychology and the new education''. Harper, and Pressey S.L. & Robinson F.P. 1944. ''Psychology and the new education''. Revised edition, Harper.</ref> is a prototypical cognitive text for student teachers. He writes (p369) of a diagnostic attack on teaching problems: :"For example, analysis of error, and remedial work based on the analysis, was found to improve greatly the mastery of algebra.<ref>Tucker G.E. 1932. An evaluation of remedial teaching in algebra. ''Educational Trends'' '''1''', 29–33.</ref> In another experiment, individualization and diagnosis caused great improvement, as shown by actual performance, in the mastery of vocational agriculture".<ref>Roberts R.W. 1932. A further study in individualized instruction. ''Journal of educational research''. '''25''', 261–266.</ref> Pressey goes on to quote more published examples, and gives the data from some of these studies. The whole of chapter 10, The nature and control of the learning process, is directly relevant to the ideas of programmed learning which developed after [[World War II]] in the [[United States]].
Pressey's whole approach to educational psychology ran in opposition to the influence of [[B.F. Skinner]] and the behaviorists, as this quotation illustrates: :"The archvillain, leading so many people astray, is declared to be learning theory! No less a charge is made than that the whole trend of American research and theory as regards learning has been based on a false premise{{mdash}}that the important features of human learning are to be found in animals. Instead, the all-important fact is that humans have transcended animal learning. Language, number, such skills as silent reading, make possible facilitations of learning, and kinds of learning, impossible even for the apes, Autoinstruction should enhance such potentials. Instead, current animal derived procedures in autoinstruction destroy meaningful structure to present material serially in programs, and replace processes of cognitive clarification and largely rote [[reinforcement]]s of bit learnings".<ref>Pressey S.L. 1963. Autopresentation vs. autoelucidation. ''Programmed instruction'' '''2''', 6–7.</ref>
